title: Hello World From Mansoura
content:
Hello, and welcome to my blog! This is my very first post, and I’m excited to start sharing my thoughts and ideas with you all. And if you don’t find my jokes funny, don’t worry, I’m a software developer, not a comedian.

First things first: let me introduce myself. My name is Franklin Osei, and I’m a Software Developer. I’m passionate about Software Engineering, and I’m always looking for new ways to learn and grow in my field.

I’m writing these blogs as a way to share my experiences and insights with others. I believe that blogging is a great way to connect with like-minded people, share ideas, and inspire others. Plus, it’s a great way to improve my writing skills and express my creativity.

Now, I have to admit that I’m a bit nervous about starting this blog. It’s a big step for me, and I’m still learning the ropes. But I’m also excited about the possibilities. I can’t wait to start sharing my knowledge, experiences, and insights with you all.

What to expect?
So, what can you expect from this blog? Well, I plan to write about a wide range of topics related to Software Engineering. I’ll share my thoughts on industry trends, discuss the latest tools and technologies, and share tips and advice based on my own experiences.

I’ll also share my personal journey and the challenges I’ve faced along the way. I hope that by sharing my experiences, I can inspire others to pursue their passions and achieve their goals.

In short, I’m here to share my story, my ideas, and my passion with you all. I hope that you’ll join me on this journey, and I promise to make it worth your while. So, keep an eye out for exciting content from me in the coming weeks and months!

Thank you for reading, and I look forward to connecting with you all soon.

title: How to tell someone you love them
content:
Watching a programme on television recently about a day in the life of a busy Accident and Emergency department, I am moved to tears by the heartfelt and earnest opening remarks of an A and E consultant:

…tell your loved ones how much they mean to you because you never know what is going to happen to you that means you never get the chance again.”

These are stark, emotionally charged words from someone who has witnessed the loss and grief of sudden tragic life-changing events all too often. 

Tell them you love them.
Our family has lived experience of this, with the sudden shocking death of a close family member only a few years ago. 

No chance to say goodbye, no final words. No chance to receive their final wisdom or how-to-live-without-me thoughts. 

I have been musing here recently on death bed regrets. You can read more on that here.

And this is another common one:

Wishing we had told others more often that we love them. 
We all like to be appreciated, and if we are honest, sometimes our focus in a relationship can be receiving love and not on as much on giving it. 

Equally, with busy and full lives, we don’t always take the time to communicate directly and specifically to those closest to us that we love them. We know in our heads that we are loved by those around us, and that we love and value them. 

Here’s the thing though:

How often do we actually say it out loud?
To them. To their face. 

I know, I know, this is not a very Scottish thing to do at all. But like all things, it gets easier with practice.

Taking those we love for granted erodes the joy in those relationships. And we risk running out of chances. I know that sounds morbid and doom-filled, but that is the reality of life. And we are not very good at talking about death. I have been to more funerals in the last few years than in all my combined years before that. Parents of friends, friends, and the heartbreaking funeral of the child of a friend. 

Life happens.

title: Hello Egypt from England
content:
After New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, the fight is on: locals make the case for the city that should be number four.

The United States is renowned for its iconic cities. New York City undoubtedly tops the list as the nation's largest city (8.5 million residents) and one of the world's great fashion, culture and finance capitals. Los Angeles comes in just behind, the US's second-most populous city and the centre of the film industry, gateway to beaches and laid-back lifestyles. The third-largest city, Chicago, was home to the world's first skyscraper and has long vied with New York in a race to build the world's tallest, most impressive buildings.

With the top three seemingly fixed, one question recently set social media aflame: what city deserves the US's fourth spot? Residents from across the country made their case, but a few consistently rose to the top – whether by population, tourism or historical importance. We asked locals what makes their city worthy of the title and why tourists should add it to their itineraries.

This centre of federal power was purposefully built to be separate from the states and serve as the nation's capital. Named after the first president, the city sits alongside the Potomac River and still reflects its early design by Peter Charles L'Enfant, anchored by The National Mall – the central stretch of federal buildings that includes Congress, Smithsonian museums and many of the US's most famous national memorials.
